title: How to Get Rid of Slugs and Snails With Yeast

steps.title: Put a lump of brewer's yeast or sprinkle powdered yeast into a jar of warm water and sugar.
steps.content: Put a lump of brewer's yeast or sprinkle powdered yeast into a jar of warm water and sugar. The jar must be deep enough to keep the slugs and snails from crawling out. You can also buy containers (traps) designed specifically for this purpose at garden supply stores. [1] X Research source A suggested mixture is two cups of warm water, a packet of dry yeast, and one teaspoonful each of salt and sugar. The salt will help ensure that the slugs and snails die before they have a chance to escape. If you're going to dump the slugs and/or mixture in your garden or compost pile, skip the salt; it'll make your soil too salty. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Dig a hole large enough for the jar to sit in up to its mouth.
steps.content: Dig a hole large enough for the jar to sit in up to its mouth. This is best done in the vegetable patch or other garden space where the slugs and snails are patrolling. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Repeat every few feet.
steps.content: Repeat every few feet. Put these traps throughout your garden at intervals of six to eight feet, since the yeast won't draw them in from any further than that.

steps.title: Check daily and remove slugs and snails that have been attracted to the jar and dispose of them.
steps.content: Check daily and remove slugs and snails that have been attracted to the jar and dispose of them. They will have crawled into the jar and drowned. You can leave them in the garden to decompose and contribute to the organic matter of the soil, or put them in a compost pile (either way, crushing them will hasten the process, if you are not squeamish about doing so). [4] X Research source

steps.title: Renew the mixture regularly.
steps.content: Renew the mixture regularly. It will be impacted by rain and evaporation, so top it up as needed. [5] X Research source
